Harm Mitigation in Recommender Systems under User Preference Dynamics

Jerry Chee jerrychee@cs.cornell.edu Cornell UniversityIthacaNYUSA ,  Shankar Kalyanaraman kshankar@meta.com MetaMenlo ParkCAUSA ,  Sindhu Kiranmai Ernala sindhuernala@meta.com MetaMenlo ParkCAUSA ,  Udi Weinsberg udi@meta.com MetaMenlo ParkCAUSA ,  Sarah Dean sdean@cornell.edu Cornell UniversityIthacaNYUSA  and  Stratis Ioannidis ioannidis@ece.neu.edu Northeastern UniversityBostonMAUSA
Abstract.

We consider a recommender system that takes into account the interplay between recommendations, the evolution of user interests, and harmful content. We model the impact of recommendations on user behavior, particularly the tendency to consume harmful content. We seek recommendation policies that establish a tradeoff between maximizing click-through rate (CTR) and mitigating harm. We establish conditions under which the user profile dynamics have a stationary point, and propose algorithms for finding an optimal recommendation policy at stationarity. We experiment on a semi-synthetic movie recommendation setting initialized with real data and observe that our policies outperform baselines at simultaneously maximizing CTR and mitigating harm.

Recommender Systems; Harm Mitigation; Amplification; User Preference Modeling
††ccs: Information systems Recommender systems††ccs: Human-centered computing Social media††This is the ArXiv version of a KDD’24 paper of the same name.

1. Introduction

The algorithm of choice for many recommender systems in production today is the classic top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendation algorithm (Karypis, 2001; Deshpande and Karypis, 2004; Cremonesi et al., 2010). In short, a top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommender uses a score function to rank items from a candidate pool and subsequently recommends the k𝑘kitalic_k highest-scoring items. Such recommendations also come with optimality guarantees: for example, if scores are proportional to a user’s selection probabilities, top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendations maximize the click-through rate (CTR) (Oh and Iyengar, 2019, 2021), i.e., the probability that the user will pick at least one item from the recommended set.

A prominent criticism against top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendations (and, more generally, maximizing engagement) is centered around the concept of amplification (Kalimeris et al., 2021), i.e., a feedback loop that arises between recommended content and user preferences. Adverse effects of amplification include decreasing content diversity and amplifying biases (Mansoury et al., 2020; Huszár et al., 2022), as well as increasing the spread of misinformation (Zhang et al., 2022) or extreme content (Restrepo et al., 2021; Whittaker et al., 2021). Recent studies also explore the impact of recommendations from a user’s perspective: recommendations may create pathways that steer users towards radicalization (Fabbri et al., 2022), polarization (Leonard et al., 2021; Levin et al., 2021) but may also aid the migration towards ever more extreme (Ribeiro et al., 2020; Restrepo et al., 2021) or even harmful content (Lin et al., 2016; Smith et al., 2022; Hou et al., 2019).

Motivated by these concerns, we model a recommender system that takes into account the interplay between recommendations and the evolution of user interests. In doing so, our work follows a long line of research in understanding the interplay between recommender systems and user behavior (see, e.g., (kalimeris2021preference; lu2014optimal; dean2022preference)). Our goal is to understand (a) the impact of recommendations on pathways towards, e.g., more extreme or harmful content, and (b) how this impact should be accounted for when making recommendations. In particular, the fundamental question that we try to answer is how should recommendations depart from top-k𝑘kitalic_k/CTR-maximizing recommendations when user preference dynamics are present, and mitigating subsequent harm is part of the objective.

Our model gives rise to complicated, interesting phenomena related to recommendation safety and harm mitigation. For example, our results (Thms. 3.4 and 4.3) suggest that naïve approaches to mitigating harm may fail catastrophically. On one hand, explicitly incorporating harm as a penalty in the recommender’s objective may have no effect in the optimal recommendation policy, if user preference dynamics are ignored. On the other hand, designing optimal recommendations when dynamics are accounted for does not come easy: surprisingly, we prove that data-mining workhorses such as alternating optimization lead to arbitrarily suboptimal recommendations. Overall, our contributions are as follows:

  • •

    We introduce a model that incorporates harm mitigation in a recommender’s objective. When user preferences are static, we show that top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendations maximize CTR while simultaneously minimizing harm. This finding suggests that to properly mitigate harm, it is necessary to account for user dynamics in the recommender’s reasoning.

  • •

    To that end, we incorporate the user preference dynamics of attraction (lu2014optimal; krauth2020offline; ge2020understanding; mansoury2020feedback), which explictly model the aforementioned amplification phenomenon. Finding optimal recommendations under these dynamics is a non-convex problem. We prove a negative result: the most natural algorithm, namely, alternating optimization, leads to recommendation policies that are in fact arbitrarily suboptimal.

  • •

    In light of this, we turn our attention to gradient-based algorithms. We propose a tractable method for computing the gradients when preference dynamics are incorporated in the objective. We also evaluate resulting gradient-based recommendation algorithms on a semi-synthetic movie recommendation setting initialized with MovieLens data, where harmful movies are determined by IMDB parental guidelines. We show that our policies are superior at maximizing CTR and mitigating harm over baselines, and perform up to 77% better.

Our model, though simple, is based on the multinomial-logit (MNL) model of choice (mcfadden1973conditional), which is ubiquitous in recommender systems literature (danaf2019online; chaptini2005use; yang2011collaborative; kalimeris2021preference). From a technical standpoint, our analysis requires characterizing the stationary point implied by the combination of recommendations with attraction dynamics; we accomplish this by using the Banach fixed point theorem. Having characterized the fixed-point, implementing gradient-based optimization algorithms in our setting poses a significant challenge, as our objective is not expressed in closed form. Nevertheless, we propose a tractable algorithm for computing gradients via the implicit function theorem.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. We discuss related work in Section 2. We define our model accounting for harm-mitigation, and determine optimal recommendations in the absence of preference dynamics in Section 3. We present our analysis under user preference dynamics in Section 4, and our empirical evaluations in Section 5. We conclude is Section 6.

2. Related Work

Characterizing Harm. The literature observing and empirically characterizing the harmful impact of algorithmic recommendations is quite extensive. Past works have experimentally observed the existence radicalization pathways (ribeiro2020auditing), polarization and filter bubbles (ledwich2022radical; levin2021dynamics; rossi2021closed), the amplification of extreme content (restrepo2021social; whittaker2021recommender), alignment with human values (gormann2022dangers), and loss of physical and mental well-being (lin2016association; smith2022recommender). Though these studies focus on empirical observations as opposed to the design of harm-mitigating recommendation policies, which is our main goal, they directly motivate our attempt to model the tension between maximizing engagement and reducing exposure to harm.

Multiple Objectives. Multi-objective recommender systems are extensively studied–see, e.g., the surveys by zheng2022survey and jannach2022multi. Examples include balancing engagement with diversity (vargas2011rank), fairness (xiao2017fairness), and multi-stakeholder utility (surer2018multistakeholder). wu2019unified propose alternate optimization and gradient-based approaches, albeit for maximizing utility when making recommendations collectively to a group of users. While not directly considering harm reduction as an objective, suna2021user propose methods to account for user polarization in matrix factorization-based recommender systems. Closer to us, singh2020building use RL to balance an engagement-based reward with a notion of harm termed the “health risk”. We depart from all these works by explicitly modeling user behavior via attraction, as well as by incorporating the possibility that users reject the recommendation and opt instead for organically-selected content. Our model allows for more interpretable decision-making (see, e.g., our discussion around Lemmas 4.1 and Thms. 3.4–4.2) as well as a better understanding of how different parameters impact optimal recommendations and the utility/harm they incur.

Multinomial-Logit Model. For the majority of our analysis, we model user preferences via the multinomial-logit (MNL) model (mcfadden1973conditional), itself an instance of the more general Plackett-Luce model (luce1959individual) (see Sec. 3). Both are used extensively to model user choices: they are workhorses in the field of econometrics, but have also found numerous applications in computer science, particularly in recommender systems (danaf2019online; chaptini2005use; yang2011collaborative; kalimeris2021preference; oh2019thompson; hazrati2022recommender; fleder2009blockbuster; jiang2014choice; koutra2017pnp). A popular theoretical setting is contextual MNL bandits, (pmlr-v65-agrawal17a; oh2019thompson; oh2021multinomial), in which a static user profile is learned online while top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendations occur; recommendation algorithms in this setting aim to minimize regret w.r.t. the CTR of an algorithm that knows the user profile. Our main departure from this literature is to model a dynamic user profile and incorporate harm. We also depart by studying recommendation policies in “steady-state”; revisiting our results in an online/bandit setting is an interesting and challenging open problem, particularly due to the user preference dynamics (maniu2020bandits; zinkevich2003online; zhang2018dynamic), which are not considered in the aforementioned MNL bandit works.

Preference Dynamics. Models of user preferences are widely used and studied in recommendation literature. Historically, the focus has been on static models (e.g. matrix factorization or topic models), but an emerging line of work models the dynamics of preferences, also termed individual feedback loops (pagan2023classification). Such models of preference dynamics formalize and illuminate phenomena like political polarization (leonard2021nonlinear; rossi2021closed) and echo chambers (perra2019modelling; jiang2019degenerate; kalimeris2021preference), in which the long term influence of recommendations plays a crucial role. Many of these works show how feedback loops lead to unintended consequences of traditional recommendation algorithms, critiquing the status quo and proposing alternative algorithms. For example, carroll2021estimating and ashton2022problem argue that recommendations which cause user preferences to shift may be viewed as inappropriate “manipulation,” while carroll2021estimating and dean2022preference propose algorithms to avoid this. While some authors propose general purpose algorithms in Markov decision processes (carroll2021estimating; tabibian2020design), most others investigate specific dynamics models connected to particular phenomena of interest. curmei2022towards advocate for a framework mapping between such preference dynamics models in computer science and known psychological effects. We note that the majority of the aforementioned works (leonard2021nonlinear; jiang2019degenerate; dean2022preference; tabibian2020design; kalimeris2021preference; rossi2021closed; pagan2023classification) study steady-state dynamics of their proposed models, as we do here; however, they do not directly optimize a recommendation policy towards attaining a certain objective in steady state.

Closest to us, lu2014optimal propose a model of user preference dynamics including attraction, aversion, and social influence. Like us, they study optimal recommendations in steady state. However, their underlying recommendation model is based on real-valued feedback in matrix factorization, as opposed to discrete user choice in the MNL model. From a technical standpoint, their dynamics are simpler, and the steady-state profiles can be computed in a closed form (rather than via a fixed point). Moreover, their recommendation design reduces to a quadratic optimization problem in their setting, which they solve via a semi-definite relaxation. Both are technically less challenging than the optimization problem we study here. Furthermore, their focus is on long term user satisfaction rather than avoiding harmful content.

Integrity Checks. Algorithms for detecting and filtering content that is inappropriate or harmful prior to recommendations, i.e. “integrity checks,” have been extensively explored by academia and industry alike (akos2021how; lee2007harmful; arora2023detecting; pierri2023does; zampieri2023offenseval; gillespie2020content). The design of such filtering mechanisms is orthogonal to the question we study. In particular, our starting point is the assumption of perfect filtering, as the recommender never suggests harmful content, which only exists outside the platform: users can find it organically irrespective of recommendations. It is natural to ask if the recommender has a role in mitigating this type of indirect harm, that it cannot directly control. Surprisingly, our work answers affirmatively. If user dynamics are present, then the recommender may cause indirect harm, and its mitigation is non-trivial: naïve ways of modeling harm or simple algorithms like alternating optimization may fail catastrophically.

Operationalization. There are many ways to conceive of and operationalize harm. In the context of recommendations, shelby2022sociotechnical and hosseini2023empirical consider representational and allocative harms. Other work considers the meaning of harm from a causal perspective, including loss of utility (beckers2022causal) and counterfactual outcome frameworks (richens2022counterfactual). We limit our scope to harm arising from engagement with problematic content. Our approach relies on modelling the causal mechanisms by which a recommender system may increase the likelihood of harm, in order to reduce it.

3. Modeling Harm-Mitigating Recommendations

We consider a recommender making sequential suggestions to a user. The user can accept the recommendation, by selecting an item in this set, or reject it, by making an “organic” selection of items that exist off-platform; this may lead to a selection of harmful content; we would like to take this into account when recommending items.

We describe here a model of this behavior assuming that user preferences are static, and characterize optimal recommendation policies; as we will see, these differ drastically from recommendations when user preference dynamics are taken into account; we consider these in the next section.

3.1. Recommendation Policies

We consider a universe of n𝑛nitalic_n items Ω⊂ℝdΩsuperscriptℝ𝑑\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}roman_Ω ⊂ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with |Ω|=nΩ𝑛|\Omega|=n| roman_Ω | = italic_n, where each item is represented by a d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional item profile v∈Ω𝑣Ωv\in\Omegaitalic_v ∈ roman_Ω (e.g., explicit features, latent factors). A subset H⊂Ω𝐻ΩH\subset\Omegaitalic_H ⊂ roman_Ω, with |H|=h𝐻ℎ|H|=h| italic_H | = italic_h, is known to be harmful. In general, set ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω includes both on-platform items, that a recommender may display to users, as well as off-platform items. At each timeslot t𝑡titalic_t, a recommender has access to a subset Ct⊆Ω∖Hsubscript𝐶𝑡Ω𝐻C_{t}\subseteq\Omega\setminus Hitalic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ roman_Ω ∖ italic_H of candidate on-platform items for possible recommendation to users. We assume that these candidate sets are sampled in an i.i.d. fashion from a collection 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C of (possibly overlapping) subsets of Ω∖HΩ𝐻\Omega\setminus Hroman_Ω ∖ italic_H. Having access to this set, the recommender displays to a user a set Et⊂Ctsubscript𝐸𝑡subscript𝐶𝑡E_{t}\subset C_{t}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; we refer to Etsubscript𝐸𝑡E_{t}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the recommended set or, simply, the recommendation.

Intuitively, the recommender could be any platform that recommends content, and ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω could be all the content on the internet, including harmful content. For example, news could be recommended on a social media platform with links out to external news sites; some “fake news” sites will never be recommended but users could still find them through other means. Note that, by design, the recommender never suggests harmful content, and harmful-content is only found off-platform.

We consider (possibly) randomized recommendation policies: given a candidate set C𝐶Citalic_C, the recommendation policy is expressed as a distribution over possible sets E⊆C𝐸𝐶E\subseteq Citalic_E ⊆ italic_C to recommend to the user. Recommendations are constrained. In the bounded cardinality setting, we assume recommended sets E𝐸Eitalic_E have at most k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}italic_k ∈ blackboard_N items. In the independent sampling setting, we assume that (a) items v∈E𝑣𝐸v\in Eitalic_v ∈ italic_E are selected independently from C𝐶Citalic_C and (b) the expected size of recommendations is at most k𝑘kitalic_k, i.e., 𝔼⁢[|E|∣C]≤k𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝐸𝐶𝑘\mathbb{E}[|E|\mid C]\leq kblackboard_E [ | italic_E | ∣ italic_C ] ≤ italic_k. Independent sampling constrains the size of E𝐸Eitalic_E only in expectation, but policies can be described with polynomially many parameters (in n,k𝑛𝑘n,kitalic_n , italic_k), compared with Θ⁢(2k)Θsuperscript2𝑘\Theta(2^{k})roman_Θ ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) parameters for bounded cardinality (see also Appendix A).

3.3. Top-k𝑘kitalic_k Recommendations

As items are linked to scores, a simple, intuitive policy is the top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendations policy (karypis2001evaluation) (see also Appendix A). Given C𝐶Citalic_C and budget k𝑘kitalic_k, the policy recommends the k𝑘kitalic_k highest-scoring items v∈C𝑣𝐶v\in Citalic_v ∈ italic_C, w.r.t., scores svsubscript𝑠𝑣s_{v}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This can be implemented in O⁢((|C|+k)⁢log⁡k)𝑂𝐶𝑘𝑘O((|C|+k)\log k)italic_O ( ( | italic_C | + italic_k ) roman_log italic_k ) time by traversing the list of scores svsubscript𝑠𝑣s_{v}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, v∈C𝑣𝐶v\in Citalic_v ∈ italic_C, and maintaining a sorted list of the highest-scoring items.

are the probabilities of click (𝙲𝙻𝙺𝙲𝙻𝙺\mathtt{CLK}typewriter_CLK) and harm (𝙷𝙷\mathtt{H}typewriter_H) events, respectively. The set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is the set of valid policies, determined either the bounded cardinality or independent sampling constraints with capacity k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}italic_k ∈ blackboard_N (see Eqs. (19) and  (20)–(21) in Appendix A). In short, Prob. (3) aims to find a valid recommendation policy π∈𝒫𝜋𝒫\pi\in\mathcal{P}italic_π ∈ caligraphic_P that establishes an optimal tradeoff between click-through rate p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and probability of harm p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as determined by parameter λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0italic_λ ≥ 0.

Note that, despite the fact that it never recommends harmful content, the recommender does impact the probability of harm: this is because it can reduce harm by attracting the user to its (non-harmful) recommendations. This has a rather suprising consequence: the top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendations policy is optimal even if the recommender objective includes harm mitigation (i.e., for all λ>0)\lambda>0)italic_λ > 0 ):

{thm}

Assume that function g:ℝ+→[0,1]:𝑔→subscriptℝ01g:\mathbb{R}_{+}\to[0,1]italic_g : blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → [ 0 , 1 ] in Eq. (1) is non-decreasing. Then for all λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0italic_λ ≥ 0 the top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendation policy is an optimal solution to Prob. (3) under the bounded cardinality setting. If, in addition, function g𝑔gitalic_g is concave, then top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendation policy is also optimal under the independent sampling setting. The proof can be found in Appendix B. It is straightforward for the bounded cardinality setting; the independent sampling case is somewhat more involved, and requires a submodularity argument. Intuitively, since the recommender never recommends harmful content, maximizing the click-through rate is also harm-minimizing: recommending content likely to be clicked reduces the chance of an organic selection and thus of selecting harmful content. Thm. 3.4 is in stark contrast to what happens when the user preferences are affected by recommendations, as we will see in the following section. Moreover, it tells an important cautionary tale: if recommenders treat users as static, recommendations that seemingly account for harm mitigation, by directly including it in the objective, may end up just maximizing click-through rate. This, however, can be catastrophic in terms of the actual harm (and the corresponding objective attained), as we will again see in the next section.

3.5. Multinomial Logit (MNL) Model

We conclude this section by presenting the standard multinomial logit (MNL) model, used extensively to model user choices in recommender systems (hazrati2022recommender; jiang2014choice; pmlr-v65-agrawal17a; oh2019thompson; oh2021multinomial; kalimeris2021preference). A special case of the Plackett-Luce model, it is a natural generalization of matrix factorization from ratings to choices, and an extension of “soft-max”, allowing for a no-choice alternative (see also Appendix D). Formally, for every v∈Ω𝑣Ωv\in\Omegaitalic_v ∈ roman_Ω, the non-negative score sv∈ℝ+subscript𝑠𝑣superscriptℝs_{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT quantifying a user’s preference toward v𝑣vitalic_v is

(5) sv≡ev⊤⁢u,subscript𝑠𝑣superscript𝑒superscript𝑣top𝑢\displaystyle s_{v}\equiv e^{v^{\top}u},italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≡ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

i.e., it is parameterized by both the item profile v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well as by a user profile u∈ℝd𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑u\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, the conditional probability p𝙲𝙻𝙺∣Esubscript𝑝conditional𝙲𝙻𝙺𝐸p_{\mathtt{CLK}\mid E}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK ∣ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by:

(6) g⁢(sE)≡sEsE+c,𝑔subscript𝑠𝐸subscript𝑠𝐸subscript𝑠𝐸𝑐\displaystyle g(s_{E})\equiv\frac{s_{E}}{s_{E}+c}~{},italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≡ divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c end_ARG ,

where c≥0𝑐0c\geq 0italic_c ≥ 0 is a non-negative constant. The remaining probabilities are given again by the Plackett-Luce model (Eq. (2)), with scores determined by Eq. (5).

It is easy to confirm that g:ℝ+→[0,1]:𝑔→subscriptℝ01g:\mathbb{R}_{+}\to[0,1]italic_g : blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → [ 0 , 1 ] is both non-decreasing and concave. Thm. 3.4 thus has the following immediate corollary: {cor} If user selections are governed by the MNL model under a static profile u∈ℝd𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑u\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then for all λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0italic_λ ≥ 0 the top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendation policy is an optimal solution to Prob. (3) under both the bounded cardinality and independent sampling settings.

4. Harm-Mitigating Recommendations Under Dynamic User Profiles

We turn our attention to what happens when user preferences adapt based on the content that users consume. As we will see, this has drastic implications for harm-mitigating recommendations. A graphical model indicating the evolution of profiles under user dynamics is shown in Fig 1.

4.1. User Profile Dynamics

For the remainder of our analysis, we adopt MNL as the model governing user choices. Thus, there exists a user profile u∈ℝd𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑u\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that, jointly with item profiles v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, determines item scores via Eq.(5). So far (e.g., in Cor. 3.5), we assumed that the user profile is static; we will now depart from this assumption.

Formally, we denote by u⁢(t)𝑢𝑡u(t)italic_u ( italic_t ) the profile of user at time t∈ℕ𝑡ℕt\in\mathbb{N}italic_t ∈ blackboard_N. Let v⁢(t)∈Ω𝑣𝑡Ωv(t)\in\Omegaitalic_v ( italic_t ) ∈ roman_Ω be the item selected and consumed by the user at timeslot t𝑡titalic_t. We model the influence of an item with an attraction model (lu2014optimal; krauth2020offline; ge2020understanding; mansoury2020feedback). First, the user is characterised by an inherent profile u0∈ℝdsubscript𝑢0superscriptℝ𝑑u_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, that captures their predisposition towards content. At time t+1𝑡1t+1italic_t + 1, the profile u⁢(t+1)𝑢𝑡1u(t+1)italic_u ( italic_t + 1 ) is generated as a convex combination of (a) the inherent profile, (b) the select item v⁢(t)𝑣𝑡v(t)italic_v ( italic_t ), and (c) the current profile u⁢(t)𝑢𝑡u(t)italic_u ( italic_t ). Formally, starting from some u⁢(0)∈ℝd𝑢0superscriptℝ𝑑u(0)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u ( 0 ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have:

(7) u⁢(t+1)=𝔼⁢[β⁢u0+αv⁢(t)⁢v⁢(t)+(1−αv⁢(t)−β)⁢u⁢(t)],𝑢𝑡1𝔼delimited-[]𝛽subscript𝑢0subscript𝛼𝑣𝑡𝑣𝑡1subscript𝛼𝑣𝑡𝛽𝑢𝑡\displaystyle u(t+1)=\mathbb{E}\left[\beta u_{0}+\alpha_{v(t)}v(t)+(1-\alpha_{% v(t)}-\beta)u(t)\right],italic_u ( italic_t + 1 ) = blackboard_E [ italic_β italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) + ( 1 - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_β ) italic_u ( italic_t ) ] ,

where the randomness is due to the selected item v⁢(t)𝑣𝑡v(t)italic_v ( italic_t ), and β∈[0,1]𝛽01\beta\in[0,1]italic_β ∈ [ 0 , 1 ], αv∈[0,1−β]subscript𝛼𝑣01𝛽\alpha_{v}\in[0,1-\beta]italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , 1 - italic_β ], v∈Ω𝑣Ωv\in\Omegaitalic_v ∈ roman_Ω, control the the relative importance of the inherent profile and the item, respectively. This is a “mean-field” or “fluid” model (borkar2009stochastic; benaim2006dynamics; benveniste2012adaptive), in which the evolution of the user profile is governed by mean dynamics. It is also an attraction model, as at every timeslot, the user profile “nudges” towards selected object v⁢(t)𝑣𝑡v(t)italic_v ( italic_t ) with a rate αv⁢(t)∈[0,1]subscript𝛼𝑣𝑡01\alpha_{v(t)}\in[0,1]italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]: by Eq. (5), this increases the probability that the user will select items similar to the ones it consumed in the past. Note that v⁢(t)𝑣𝑡v(t)italic_v ( italic_t ) is a random variable whose distribution depends on the recommendation policy π𝜋\piitalic_π and the current user profile u⁢(t)𝑢𝑡u(t)italic_u ( italic_t ) (see Eq. (27)). In general, we allow the “attractiveness” to be content dependent. For simplicity of exposition, from here forward, we assume that αv=α𝙷,subscript𝛼𝑣subscript𝛼𝙷\alpha_{v}=\alpha_{\mathtt{H}},italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , if v∈H,𝑣𝐻v\in H,italic_v ∈ italic_H , and αv=α𝙽𝙷,subscript𝛼𝑣subscript𝛼𝙽𝙷\alpha_{v}=\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}},italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , if v∉H.𝑣𝐻v\notin H.italic_v ∉ italic_H .

Stationary Profiles and Steady State Behavior. A profile u¯∈ℝd¯𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑\bar{u}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is stationary when Δ⁢u⁢(t)=0Δ𝑢𝑡0\Delta u(t)=0roman_Δ italic_u ( italic_t ) = 0 for u⁢(t)=u¯𝑢𝑡¯𝑢u(t)=\bar{u}italic_u ( italic_t ) = over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG: that is, if the system starts from this profile, it will remain there indefinitely. 4.2. Recommendation Objective

We are now ready to revisit our recommendation objective. We denote by Πdouble-struck-Π\mathbb{\Pi}blackboard_Π the set of all possible recommendation policies (including invalid ones, not in 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P). Given policy π∈Π𝜋double-struck-Π\pi\in\mathbb{\Pi}italic_π ∈ blackboard_Π, let π↦u¯⁢(π)maps-to𝜋¯𝑢𝜋\pi\mapsto\bar{u}(\pi)italic_π ↦ over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π ) be the map from π𝜋\piitalic_π to the stationary profile u¯¯𝑢\bar{u}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG, as defined above (see also Eq. (10) below). We consider the following optimization problem:

(9a) Maximize::Maximizeabsent\displaystyle\text{Maximize}:Maximize : f⁢(π)=p𝙲𝙻𝙺⁢(π,u¯⁢(π))−λ⁢p𝙷⁢(π,u¯⁢(π))𝑓𝜋subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺𝜋¯𝑢𝜋𝜆subscript𝑝𝙷𝜋¯𝑢𝜋\displaystyle~{}~{}f(\pi)=p_{\mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,\bar{u}(\pi))\!-\!\lambda p_{% \mathtt{H}}(\pi,\bar{u}(\pi))italic_f ( italic_π ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π , over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π ) ) - italic_λ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π , over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π ) )
(9b) subj. to::subj. toabsent\displaystyle\text{subj.~{}to}:subj. to : π∈𝒫,𝜋𝒫\displaystyle~{}~{}\pi\in\mathcal{P},italic_π ∈ caligraphic_P ,

for some regularization parameter λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0italic_λ ≥ 0. Crucially, both the CTR and the probability of harm are measured at the stationary profile u¯⁢(π)¯𝑢𝜋\bar{u}(\pi)over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π ), our proxy for the steady-state limit of the user dynamics. Note that, even though the recommendation policy never suggests harmful content, recommendations affect user selections, which in turn affect their predisposition towards harmful content.

Solving Prob. (9) is quite challenging. Beyond the fact that it is not a convex optimization problem, finding a solution is complicated by the fact that the stationary profiles depend on the recommendation policy π𝜋\piitalic_π via map u¯⁢(π)¯𝑢𝜋\bar{u}(\pi)over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π ), which we cannot express in a closed-form. Thus, we have no direct way of computing it; it is a priori unclear even whether such a stationary profile exists and is unique. One of our contributions is to resolve both of these issues (see Thm. 4.2).

Computing u¯⁢(π)¯𝑢𝜋\bar{u}(\pi)over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π ). We now turn our attention to finding the stationary user profile. We fist characterize the stationary profile via a fixed-point equation. Eq. (8) implies the following lemma:

We prove this in Appendix E. Thm. 4.2 along with the Banach fixed-point theorem (banach1922operations) imply that a stationary profile exists and is unique when Eq. (12) holds. Most importantly, it can be found by the following iterative process: starting from any u¯0∈ℝdsuperscript¯𝑢0superscriptℝ𝑑\bar{u}^{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the iterations

(13) u¯ℓ+1=F⁢(π,u¯ℓ),ℓ∈ℕ,formulae-sequencesuperscript¯𝑢ℓ1𝐹𝜋superscript¯𝑢ℓℓℕ\displaystyle\bar{u}^{\ell+1}=F(\pi,\bar{u}^{\ell}),\quad\ell\in\mathbb{N},over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_F ( italic_π , over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , roman_ℓ ∈ blackboard_N ,

are guaranteed to converge to the unique fixed-point u¯∗superscript¯𝑢\bar{u}^{*}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Eq. (10). Convergence happens exponentially fast (see Appendix. E).

Note that Eq. (12) holds w.l.o.g.: multiplying every v∈Ω𝑣Ωv\in\Omegaitalic_v ∈ roman_Ω with a constant τ<1𝜏1\tau<1italic_τ < 1 and u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with 1/τ1𝜏1/\tau1 / italic_τ yields exactly the same scores in Eq. (5). Hence, inherent user profiles and item profiles learned from data (e.g., user-item clicks), can be rescaled so that Eq. (12) holds.

4.3. Alternating Optimization

Armed with Thm. 4.2, we turn our attention to algorithms for solving the (non-convex) Prob. (9) in its general form. A simple approach is via an alternating optimization/EM-like algorithm. In particular, one could start from, e.g., the user’s initial profile u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and iterate as follows, for ℓ∈ℕℓℕ\ell\in\mathbb{N}roman_ℓ ∈ blackboard_N:

(14a) πℓ+1superscript𝜋ℓ1\displaystyle\pi^{\ell+1}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =arg⁡maxπ∈𝒫(p𝙲𝙻𝙺⁢(π,uℓ)−λ⁢p𝙷⁢(π,uℓ)),absentsubscript𝜋𝒫subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺𝜋superscript𝑢ℓ𝜆subscript𝑝𝙷𝜋superscript𝑢ℓ\displaystyle=\textstyle\mathop{\arg\,\max}_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}}\left(p_{% \mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,u^{\ell})-\lambda p_{\mathtt{H}}(\pi,u^{\ell})\right),= start_BIGOP roman_arg roman_max end_BIGOP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ∈ caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_λ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ,
(14b) uℓ+1superscript𝑢ℓ1\displaystyle u^{\ell+1}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =u¯⁢(πℓ).absent¯𝑢superscript𝜋ℓ\displaystyle=\bar{u}(\pi^{\ell}).= over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

In step (14a), given uℓsuperscript𝑢ℓu^{\ell}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the optimal π𝜋\piitalic_π is determined by the top-k𝑘kitalic_k policy (by Thm. 3.4). In step (14b), given πℓsuperscript𝜋ℓ\pi^{\ell}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the map u¯¯𝑢\bar{u}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG is computed via the iterative algorithm in Eq. (13). The algorithm thus alternates between finding an optimal recommendation policy and the corresponding stationary profile. Unfortunately, this approach fails: {thm} The alternating optimization steps in Algorithm (14) can be arbitrarily suboptimal: for every M>0𝑀0M>0italic_M > 0, we can construct an instance of Prob. (9) with optimal solution π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for which the solution π𝜋\piitalic_π produced by Algorithm (14) satisfies f⁢(π∗)−f⁢(π)>M𝑓superscript𝜋𝑓𝜋𝑀f(\pi^{*})-f(\pi)>Mitalic_f ( italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f ( italic_π ) > italic_M. The proof is in Appendix F. On a high level, even though Alg. (14) produces a different solution than the top-k𝑘kitalic_k policy with profile u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as it takes into account the steady state profile, Thm. 3.4 implies that this trajectory is independent of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ. This leads to arbitrarily suboptimal decisions when λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ is high, and minimizing the probability of harm is paramount.

4.4. Gradient-Based Algorithms

The suboptimality of alternating optimization highlights the importance of understanding the evolution π𝜋\piitalic_π and u¯⁢(π)¯𝑢𝜋\bar{u}(\pi)over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π ) jointly. This can indeed be accomplished via a continuous optimization algorithm like projected gradient ascent (PGA) (bertsekas1997nonlinear). The constraint set in both the bounded cardinality and the independent sampling settings is a convex polytope. Applying first-order methods to solve this requires computing the gradient of the objective (9a). However, this poses a challenge exactly because we cannot describe u¯⁢(⋅)¯𝑢⋅\bar{u}(\cdot)over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( ⋅ ) in closed form. Nevertheless, we show that ∇u¯⁢(⋅)∇¯𝑢⋅\nabla\bar{u}(\cdot)∇ over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( ⋅ ) and, subsequently ∇f⁢(⋅)∇𝑓⋅\nabla f(\cdot)∇ italic_f ( ⋅ ), can be computed using the implicit function theorem (folland2001advanced; blondel2022efficient). We briefly review PGA for the bounded cardinality setting below, and provide implementation details for PGA in both constraint settings in the supplement. Nevertheless, we stress that these gradients can be used in other standard solvers; we demonstrate this in our experiments, where we use the (more powerful) SLSQP solver (kraft1988software) instead.

Computational Complexity and Tractability. For the bounded cardinality setting, gradient computations via Eqs. (16)–(17) involve (a) linear algebra operations (matrix multiplications, solving linear systems) and (b) computing the stationary point u¯⁢(π)¯𝑢𝜋\bar{u}(\pi)over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_π ). The former can be done in polynomial time in constituent matrix dimensions m𝑚mitalic_m and d𝑑ditalic_d. The latter can be computed via the iterations in Eq. (13): each iteration is again polynomial in m𝑚mitalic_m and d𝑑ditalic_d, and convergence is exponentially fast (see also the discussion below Thm. 4.2). Having computed the gradient, using Michelot’s algorithm (michelot1986finite), the projection in Eq. (15) is O⁢(m⁢log⁡m)𝑂𝑚𝑚O(m\log m)italic_O ( italic_m roman_log italic_m ), while the remaining operations in PGA steps (15) are linear in m𝑚mitalic_m. Finally, all of the above statements extend to the independent sampling setting, with m𝑚mitalic_m replaced by m′≡∑C∈𝒞|C|superscript𝑚′subscript𝐶𝒞𝐶m^{\prime}\equiv\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}|C|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≡ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_C | (see Appendices A and G).

We stress that bounded cardinality setting operations are efficient only if m𝑚mitalic_m is polynomial in n𝑛nitalic_n; this is the case only when k𝑘kitalic_k is fixed (e.g., when k=3𝑘3k=3italic_k = 3), and the recommender only recommends a few items to the user. In contrast, as m′=∑C∈𝒞|C|superscript𝑚′subscript𝐶𝒞𝐶m^{\prime}=\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}|C|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C ∈ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_C |, the independent sampling setting can be polynomial in n𝑛nitalic_n for all k𝑘kitalic_k: for example, if 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is a partition of Ω∖HΩ𝐻\Omega\setminus Hroman_Ω ∖ italic_H, then m′=n−hsuperscript𝑚′𝑛ℎm^{\prime}=n-hitalic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_n - italic_h, which does not depend on k𝑘kitalic_k.

5. Experiments

5.1. Experimental Setup

Dataset. We use the MovieLens25m dataset to extract movie and item profiles and the IMDB parental guideline ratings (Hay2023; IMDBParent) to determine our definition of harmful movies. The IMDB parental guideline ratings comprise 5 categories: (1) Sex & Nudity, (2) Violence & Gore, (3) Profanity, (4) Alcohol, Drugs, & Smoking, and (5) Frightening & Intense Scenes. For these experiments, we consider a movie harmful if it is “Severe”—the worst parental rating—in any of these categories. We join the MovieLens25m dataset with the IMDB data set via the IMDB movie identifiers, and then create 5 sub-datasets by filtering containing movies from 5 categories: “Action”, “Adventure”, “Comedy”, “Fantasy”, and “Sci-Fi”. We restrict each dataset to the 100 movies with the most ratings and 100 users, with user and movie profiles of dimension d=12𝑑12d=12italic_d = 12 constructed via matrix factorization. Learned profiles play the role of u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v𝑣vitalic_v in our experiments. Full details on the this pre-processing pipeline, including hyperparameters, can be found in Appendix H. We make our code publicly available.111https://github.com/jerry-chee/HarmMitigation

Model Parameters. We use MF user profiles as u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (inherent profiles), and item profiles v𝑣vitalic_v as extracted from the above matrix factorization process. We use these values into our model to compute the steady-state behavior of each of different policies, but also simulate the evolution of the user profiles under these policies. Unless otherwise noted, we use α𝙷=0.25subscript𝛼𝙷0.25\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}=0.25italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.25, a𝙽𝙷=0.5subscript𝑎𝙽𝙷0.5a_{\mathtt{NH}}=0.5italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5, β=0.15𝛽0.15\beta=0.15italic_β = 0.15, and λ=100𝜆100\lambda=100italic_λ = 100 (though we also explore the impact of these parameters). Unless otherwise noted, we use k=1𝑘1k=1italic_k = 1 under the bounded cardinality setting for most experiments, exploring the impact of k𝑘kitalic_k on recommendations separately under the independent sampling setting. We calibrate c𝑐citalic_c in function g𝑔gitalic_g (Eq. (33)) in the range [1,20]120[1,20][ 1 , 20 ] to balance the steady-state mean p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( Eq.(4)) under a benchmark recommendation policy (the uniform recommendation policy, described below). The full set of values of c𝑐citalic_c per dataset, as well as the corresponding justification for these choices, is given in Appendix H.

As we use profiles learned from data, rather than user ratings directly, our experiments are semi-synthetic. Note that going beyond semi-synthetic experiments poses several challenges which we share with the broader recommender system literature (e.g., oh2019thompson; oh2021multinomial): assessing the performance of different policies would require knowing how a user would react to alternatives they have not seen, which we cannot extract from offline datasets.

Algorithms. We implement the following algorithms: Gradient-Based Algorithm (Grad) is the SLSQP implementation of SciPy (2020SciPy-NMeth), for both the bounded cardinality and the independent sampling setting, using our gradient computation approach as described in Sec. 4 and Appendix. G; Alternating Optimization (Alt) is is the (suboptimal) alternating optimization algorithm in Eq. (14); Static Profile Optimization (U0) is the optimal policy under static profile u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as determined by Thm. 3.4; finally, Uniform Recommendations (Unif) is the policy that selects the recommended set u.a.r. Additional implementation details, including convergence tolerance criteria, are in Appendix H. We stress here that, as Prob. (9) is non-convex, it is not a priori clear that Grad reaches a globally optimal policy.

Metrics. We report the recommendation objective (Eq. (9)), as well as its constituent p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also measure ‖limt→∞u⁢(t)−u¯‖normsubscript→𝑡𝑢𝑡¯𝑢\|\lim_{t\to\infty}u(t)-\bar{u}\|∥ roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_t ) - over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ∥ (Eq. (7),(10)), the distance of the user profile dynamics as time evolves under a given policy and the corresponding fixed point.

5.2. Results

Recommendation Policy Comparison. Table 2 reports our key metrics over the 5 movie genre data sets, averaged across the 100 users in the dataset. Across all genre datasets, Grad attains superior recommendation objective values, while the improvement over uniform is as much as 77% (for Sci-Fi). Surprisingly, our policy does not need to sacrifice p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to attain low p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in comparison to other policies; it is superior in both terms. This is because it recommends an item (a) users become more likely to click, in steady state, and (b) is distinct enough from harmful content, so that p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains low.

We note that, even though we report standard deviations, Grad dominates other policies in terms of the objective also on a per user basis: this is evident in Fig. 2, where we report also the PDFs of the difference of objectives from the one attained by Grad (additional genres are in the appendix). In Fig. 3, we visualize the which movies each policy recommends for two users in the Action and Adventure genres. We display each vector v𝑣vitalic_v with respect to their inner product with the mean non-harmful and harmful vector. We observe that the gradient-based policy is more concentrated towards the right, i.e., on movies which have high inner product with the average non-harmful vector. Similar observations hold for remaining genres (see Fig. 7 in Appendix H).

Understanding the Effect of Model Parameters. We plot the effect of modifying λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, β𝛽\betaitalic_β, and c𝑐citalic_c on the objective attained by different policies for the Action genre in Fig. 4; additional genres, as well as the effect these parameters have on p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are shown in Figs. 11–13 in Appendix H. Increasing any parameter decreases the objective attained by every policy, which is intuitive. We also observe that increasing λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ naturally increases the performance gap of the Grad policy. Increasing β𝛽\betaitalic_β has the opposite effect, as it limits the ability of all policies to impact a user’s profile. Parameter c𝑐citalic_c also increases the improvement of Grad over other policies as, the larger c𝑐citalic_c is, the less likely the recommendation is to be accepted, and the more important it becomes to minimize harm.

In Fig. 5, we also plot the impact of the ratio α𝙷/α𝙽𝙷subscript𝛼𝙷subscript𝛼𝙽𝙷\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}/\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the objective attained by different policies for the Action and Adventure genres. Increasing the ratio decreases the objective attained by every policy as well as the gap from Grad, as policies have less leeway in minimizing harm. Similar observations hold for other genres (see Figs. 14–16 in Appendix H).

Convergence. For all datasets, policies, and users in the experiments reported in Table 2, we also compute the user profile dynamics in Eq. (7). In all experiments, they converge to the corresponding stationary user profile in Lemma 4.1, within a 10−3superscript10310^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tolerance; see Table 3 for per genre tolerances.

Increasing Recommendation Size under the Independent Sampling Setting. Next, we study the scalability of our algorithms by increasing the recommendation size k𝑘kitalic_k, under the independent sampling setting. In Fig. 6 we plot the impact of k𝑘kitalic_k on the objective for the Action genre, under two different scenarios: in one, we vary c𝑐citalic_c along with k𝑘kitalic_k, while in the other we keep it fixed. Intuitively, as k𝑘kitalic_k increases, p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges to one, and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT collapses to zero. Thus, to better understand the performance of different policies as k𝑘kitalic_k increases we make the optimization “harder” as we increase k𝑘kitalic_k. To accomplish this, recall from Sec. 3 the total score of a recommendes set E⊆Ω𝐸ΩE\subseteq\Omegaitalic_E ⊆ roman_Ω is SE≡∑v∈Esvsubscript𝑆𝐸subscript𝑣𝐸subscript𝑠𝑣S_{E}\equiv\sum_{v\in E}s_{v}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≡ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and that the conditional probability p𝙲𝙻𝙺|E=g⁢(sE)≡sE/(sE+c)subscript𝑝conditional𝙲𝙻𝙺𝐸𝑔subscript𝑠𝐸subscript𝑠𝐸subscript𝑠𝐸𝑐p_{\mathtt{CLK}|E}=g(s_{E})\equiv s_{E}/(s_{E}+c)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK | italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c ). Assuming SEsubscript𝑆𝐸S_{E}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT grows proportionally with k𝑘kitalic_k, setting c𝑐citalic_c to also grow proportionally with k𝑘kitalic_k keeps p𝙲𝙻𝙺|Esubscript𝑝conditional𝙲𝙻𝙺𝐸p_{\mathtt{CLK}|E}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK | italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT relatively constant, allowing us to better understand how increasing k𝑘kitalic_k effects harm. In Fig. 6(a), when c𝑐citalic_c is fixed, we see that all policies improve (as expected) w.r.t. the overal objective, with Grad dominating other policies. In Fig. 6(b), when c𝑐citalic_c is proportional to k𝑘kitalic_k, the problem becomes harder and the objective decreases, with Grad still being dominant; this is confirmed when observing the impact on p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, reported in Appendix H.

6. Conclusions

Overall, our goal is to gain a better understanding of real-world phenomena through a simplified but insightful model. We study a model in which the likelihood of consuming harmful content, though never directly the result of a recommendation, can nonetheless be influenced by a recommendation policy through its impact on user preferences. The notion of harm that we study is simple: content is known to be either harmful or non-harmful, and recommenders will never recommend harmful content. Despite this, considerable complexity arises from the user behavior model which is influenced on both short (via clicks) and long (via interests) timescales by the choices of the recommender. We develop algorithms for designing recommenders which simultaneously maximize a CTR objective while minimizing the likelihood of harm and verify their performance on a setting initialized with real movie rating data. We present compelling evidence that a user pathway to harm should be accounted for; this is missing in both literature and practice. We rigorously substantiate that solely maximizing the click-through-rate may come at the cost of shifting user preferences towards harm.

Our focus on the long term impacts of recommendations leads to conceptions of harm that are both mathematically challenging and conceptually rich. Many opportunities for future work remain in the setting that we study, for example: under what conditions are user profiles guaranteed to converge to a fixed point? Is it possible to make guarantees about tractable algorithms for optimizing our non-convex objective? Many open questions arise from relaxing our assumptions, like: what if users interests evolve according to something other than attraction (e.g. repulsion (lu2014optimal), biased assimilation (dean2022preference)). What if user and item profiles are not directly observed, and must be learned from data? Finally, we hope that our perspective, centered on the dynamics of users, can contribute to the rich literature on harms caused by algorithmic systems and inspire effective methods for mitigation.

Bounded Cardinality. In this setting, only sets E𝐸Eitalic_E of cardinality |E|≤k𝐸𝑘|E|\leq k| italic_E | ≤ italic_k may be recommended, for some k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}italic_k ∈ blackboard_N. Formally, given C∈𝒞𝐶𝒞C\in\mathcal{C}italic_C ∈ caligraphic_C, let

Top-k𝑘kitalic_k Recommendations. A simple, intuitive deterministic policy is the top-k𝑘kitalic_k recommendations policy [karypis2001evaluation, deshpande2004item, cremonesi2010performance]. Conversely, an optimization over policies π∈𝒫𝜋𝒫\pi\in\mathcal{P}italic_π ∈ caligraphic_P, with 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P defined by Eqs. (19) or  (20)–(21), the top-k𝑘kitalic_k policy is included as a valid policy.

Consider next the case where 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is given by Eqs. (20)–(21) (i.e., the independent sampling setting). Appendix D Multinomial Logit (MNL) Model.

We give here a more detailed description of the standard multinomial logit (MNL). MNL special case of the Plackett-Luce model, and it is popular in modeling user choices in recommender, search engine, and ad display settings [danaf2019online, chaptini2005use, yang2011collaborative]. This is precisely because it has several useful and natural properties. First, it is a natural generalization of matrix factorization [koren2009matrix] from ratings to choices, as scores depend on the inner product v⊤⁢usuperscript𝑣top𝑢v^{\top}uitalic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u (i.e., how well item and user profiles are “aligned”). It is also a natural extension of “soft-max”, allowing for a no-choice alternative. We elaborate further in these connections below.

Formally, under MNL, for every v∈Ω𝑣Ωv\in\Omegaitalic_v ∈ roman_Ω, the non-negative score sv∈ℝ+subscript𝑠𝑣superscriptℝs_{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT quantifying a user’s preference toward v𝑣vitalic_v is

(29) sv≡ev⊤⁢u,subscript𝑠𝑣superscript𝑒superscript𝑣top𝑢\displaystyle s_{v}\equiv e^{v^{\top}u},italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≡ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

i.e., it is parameterized by both the item profile v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well as by a user profile u∈ℝd𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑u\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, the conditional probability p𝙲𝙻𝙺∣Esubscript𝑝conditional𝙲𝙻𝙺𝐸p_{\mathtt{CLK}\mid E}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK ∣ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given: by

(30) g⁢(SE)≡sEsE+c.𝑔subscript𝑆𝐸subscript𝑠𝐸subscript𝑠𝐸𝑐\displaystyle g(S_{E})\equiv\frac{s_{E}}{s_{E}+c}~{}.italic_g ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≡ divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c end_ARG .

where c≥0𝑐0c\geq 0italic_c ≥ 0 is a non-negative constant. The remaining probabilities are given again by the Plackett-Luce model (Eq. (2)), with scores determined by (5).

In particular, conditioned on recommendation E𝐸Eitalic_E, the probability that the user selects (i.e., clicks) on item v∈E𝑣𝐸v\in Eitalic_v ∈ italic_E is given by:

(31) pv∧𝙲𝙻𝙺∣E=svsE+c,for ⁢v∈E,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑣conditional𝙲𝙻𝙺𝐸subscript𝑠𝑣subscript𝑠𝐸𝑐for 𝑣𝐸\displaystyle p_{v\land\mathtt{CLK}\mid E}=\frac{s_{v}}{s_{E}+c},\quad\text{% for }v\in E,italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∧ typewriter_CLK ∣ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c end_ARG , for italic_v ∈ italic_E ,

where c≥0𝑐0c\geq 0italic_c ≥ 0 is a non-negative constant. In other words, the probability that v∈E𝑣𝐸v\in Eitalic_v ∈ italic_E is selected is proportional to sv∈ℝ+subscript𝑠𝑣superscriptℝs_{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and is, in effect, a “soft-max” over inner products v⊤⁢usuperscript𝑣top𝑢v^{\top}uitalic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u, v∈E𝑣𝐸v\in Eitalic_v ∈ italic_E, with c𝑐citalic_c controling the no-choice alternative.

This means that the first application of F𝐹Fitalic_F to u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will produce a vector that will contain a high value (at least 0.6⁢B20.6subscript𝐵20.6B_{2}0.6 italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) on the second coordinate, and a negative value (at most −0.6⁢B20.6subscript𝐵2-0.6B_{2}- 0.6 italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) on the third coordinate. Repeated applications of F𝐹Fitalic_F will make the contribution of v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v𝙷subscript𝑣𝙷v_{\mathtt{H}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT higher, simultaneously suppressing the contribution of v1subscript𝑣1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the latter will have a score e−Θ⁢(B22)superscript𝑒Θsuperscriptsubscript𝐵22e^{-\Theta(B_{2}^{2})}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Θ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As a result, the fixed point u¯¯𝑢\bar{u}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG will contain a larger contribution from v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v𝙷subscript𝑣𝙷v_{\mathtt{H}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, hence, the second coordinate will be positive and of order Θ⁢(B2)Θsubscript𝐵2\Theta(B_{2})roman_Θ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), while the third coordinate will be negative and of order −Θ⁢(B2)Θsubscript𝐵2-\Theta(B_{2})- roman_Θ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Thus, in the next iteration of the alternating optimization algorithm, v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will again be selected as an optimal recommendation, and the algorithm will terminate (as u¯¯𝑢\bar{u}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG/π𝜋\piitalic_π) will again be the same). At this operating point, however, as u¯¯𝑢\bar{u}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG has a non-zero, positive second coordinate, the probability of harm will be non-zero. In fact, it will be arbitrarily close to 1-pv0subscript𝑝subscript𝑣0p_{v_{0}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the probability of selecting of v1subscript𝑣1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be negligible. Moreover, pv0subscript𝑝subscript𝑣0p_{v_{0}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be bounded away from 1, as the probability of organic selection of v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v𝙷subscript𝑣𝙷v_{\mathtt{H}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be comparable for large B2subscript𝐵2B_{2}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (approximately ≈0.5absent0.5\approx 0.5≈ 0.5).

A very different behavior will occur however if v1subscript𝑣1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is recommended. By our choice of c𝑐citalic_c, this will again be selected with probability >0.8absent0.8>0.8> 0.8, and repeated applications of F𝐹Fitalic_F will lead to a u¯¯𝑢\bar{u}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG that has a θB2subscript𝜃subscript𝐵2\theta_{B_{2}}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT For the same reasons, u¯¯𝑢\bar{u}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG will have a high positive value (Θ⁢(B1)Θsubscript𝐵1\Theta(B_{1})roman_Θ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) on the last coordinate and a high negative value (-Θ⁢(B2)Θsubscript𝐵2\Theta(B_{2})roman_Θ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) on the second coordinate. As a result, the probability (organic) selection of both v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v1subscript𝑣1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be arbitrarily small under the stationary profile constructed by this recommendation policy.

The (approximate) symmetry between recommending v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v1subscript𝑣1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the u¯¯𝑢\bar{u}over¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARGs they lead to imply that these two policies will have a very similar p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; in contrast, they will have very different p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: this is precisely because with the first the probability of selecting v𝙷subscript𝑣𝙷v_{\mathtt{H}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is non-negligible and comparable to the one selecting v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, whereas with the second p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is negligible. Hence, by appropriately setting λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, we can make the gap between the utilities constructed by two polices arbitrarily large. ∎

This is classic (see, e.g., [calinescu2011maximizing]) and has a long history of use in submodular optimization [calinescu2011maximizing, hassani2017gradient]. The function Z⁢(ρ)=𝔼ρC⁢[z⁢(E)]𝑍𝜌subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝐶delimited-[]𝑧𝐸Z(\rho)=\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}[z(E)]italic_Z ( italic_ρ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_z ( italic_E ) ] is known as the multi-linear relaxation of z𝑧zitalic_z, and Chernoff bounds can be used to characterize the quality of the above approximations; moreover, provided z𝑧zitalic_z is bounded (which is indeed the case for all functions we compute here) a polynomial number of samples N𝑁Nitalic_N is required for the above estimators to get within a given accuracy from the true expectation (see, e.g., Sec. 3 in calinescu2011maximizing).

These sampling techniques can be applied directly to our independent sampling setting, again combined with an appropriate combination of chain rules the an appropriate evocation of the implicit function theorem.

Appendix H Additional Experimental Details and Results

H.1. Experimental Setup

We join the MovieLens25m ratings, movies, and links csv files by movieId, and then join with the IMDB dataset [IMDBParent] by the same column. We filter on the desired genre, and then select the top 100 movies with the highest number of ratings, and the subsequent top 1000 users by the number of these movies that they have rated. A matrix factorization model is trained using this user-movie ratings matrix with dimension 10 as well as additional user and item level biases. We use stochastic gradient descent over the mean squared error, with learning rate of 0.01, regularization parameter of 0.01, and 100 iterations. This process results in learned 12 dimensional user and item embeddings. The RMSE of these learned embeddings are as follows: Action: 1.39, Adventure: 1.49, Comedy: 1.54, Fantasy: 1.86, Sci-Fi: 1.59. For the simulations, we select a set of 100 users per genre u.a.r., with a fixed random seed of 42. Experiments were conducted on a CPU cluster with slurm management. To compute the embeddings, 100G of memory and 10 CPUs were requested. The matrix factorization implementation we used is a modified from an open source repository.222 https://github.com/albertauyeung/matrix-factorization-in-python

p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Calibration with c𝑐citalic_c. The parameter c𝑐citalic_c in the multinomial logit model (6) influences the effectiveness of our policies in garnering clicks and therefore guiding user dynamics. For any given sEsubscript𝑠𝐸s_{E}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as c→∞→𝑐c\to\inftyitalic_c → ∞, g→0→𝑔0g\to 0italic_g → 0. By calibrating c𝑐citalic_c, we can influence p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT so that our simulations are in a regime where harm matters. For each genre we take a random sample of 10 users, and compute the resulting p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under the uniform and alternating policies, at steady state user dynamics. Table 4 shows the results for each genre, and the chosen value of c𝑐citalic_c, for k=1𝑘1k=1italic_k = 1 under the bounded cardinality setting. Our heuristic is to choose c𝑐citalic_c for each genre maximizing p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that p𝙲𝙻𝙺>0.5subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺0.5p_{\mathtt{CLK}}>0.5italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.5 under the Alt policy.

Algorithm Implementation Details. Fixed-point operations (Eq. (13)) executed for at most τ=10𝜏10\tau=10italic_τ = 10 iterations, and always converged within a 10−3superscript10310^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tolerance, irrespective of whether conditions of Thm. 4.2 were satisfied. Unless otherwise noted, all recommendation policies operate in the Bounded Cardinality setting (Sec. 4.2).

Additional algorithm implementation details per algorithm are as follows:

  • •

    Gradient-Based Algorithm (Grad). We implement a gradient-based algorithm solving Prob. (9) using the SLSQP implementation of SciPy [2020SciPy-NMeth]. For the bounded cardinality setting, we encode constraints such that the sum of the policy vector is 1, and each entry of the policy vector is non-negative. For the independent sampling setting, we encode constraints such that the sum of the policy vector is k𝑘kitalic_k, and each entry lies within the interval [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ]. We set SLSQP precision tolerance to ftol=10−4absentsuperscript104=10^{-4}= 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Because this is a non-convex optimization problem, we start the SLSQP procedure at various starting points and choose the resulting policy which achieves the best objective. For starting points we use: U0 policy, Unif policy, Unif “interior” policy (dividing the vector by 100 to reach an interior point of the constraints), 3 random initalizations such that the sum of the policy vector is 1, and 3 random “interior” initalizations taking the previous random vector and dividing by 100.

  • •

    Alternating Optimization (Alt). We also implement alternating optimization (Sec. 4.3) for 10 steps; in all our experiments, user profiles converged with tolerance less than 2.5×10−32.5superscript1032.5\times 10^{-3}2.5 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, in ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distance.

  • •

    Static Profile Optimization (U0). As an additional baseline, we consider the policy maximizing the objective under a static user profile, i.e., Eq. (3) with user profile u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • •

    Uniform Recommendations (Unif). We also implement recommending uniformly at random as a baseline. For the bounded cardinality setting, that is πE=1/|𝒟|,subscript𝜋𝐸1𝒟\pi_{E}=1/|\mathcal{D}|,italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 / | caligraphic_D | , for E∈𝒟𝐸𝒟E\in\mathcal{D}italic_E ∈ caligraphic_D, and ρv=k/n′subscript𝜌𝑣𝑘superscript𝑛′\rho_{v}=k/n^{\prime}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, for v∈Ω∖H𝑣Ω𝐻v\in\Omega\setminus Hitalic_v ∈ roman_Ω ∖ italic_H, for the independent sampling setting.

Profile Evolution. We also implement the time evolution of a user profile under a given recommendation policy, always starting from u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We iterate over Eq. (⁢7⁢)italic-(7italic-)\eqref{eq:u}italic_( italic_) until ‖u⁢(t+1)−u⁢(t)‖∞<10−3subscriptnorm𝑢𝑡1𝑢𝑡superscript103\|u(t+1)-u(t)\|_{\infty}<10^{-3}∥ italic_u ( italic_t + 1 ) - italic_u ( italic_t ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Programming and Experimental Environment. All code was written in Python 3.10, using numpy 1.21.5, pandas 1.5.2, and scipy 1.9.3. Experiments were conducted on a CPU cluster with slurm management. Each genre and experimental configuration was parallelized across users by running multiple slurm jobs. To learn the policies, 1G of memory and 5 CPUs were requested for each parallelized job.

H.2. Additional Experimental Results

Per-User Policy Performance Comparison. Fig. 8 shows the PDF of the difference between the objective attained by different policies minus the objective by attained by Grad, for the same experimental settings as in Table 2. For the overwelming majority of users, the objective attained by other policies is below the ones attained by Grad. These insights are also reflected in the plots for p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Figures 9 and 10, respectively.

Understanding the Effect of Model Parameters. We plot the change in the objective as we modify parameters for different genres in Figure 11. We observe the same patterns we saw in Fig. 4 for the Action genre. As the user coefficient β𝛽\betaitalic_β increases, we see a consistent degradation in performance for the policies (gradient, alternating) which account for user dynamics. This is expected as higher β𝛽\betaitalic_β makes a user more resistant to changing their initial profile. As the recommendation efficacy decreases (higher c𝑐citalic_c), we see that p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases as users go to more 𝙾𝚁𝙶𝙾𝚁𝙶\mathtt{ORG}typewriter_ORG interactions.

We also plot the corresponding p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values in Figures 12 and Figure 13, respectively. As we increase the harm penalty λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ we see that p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remain stable. We see an improved performance on the grad policy when λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0italic_λ = 0 w.r.t. p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is counterintuitive. This could be either because the problem is highly non-convex, and none of the above solutions are guaranteed to be optimal, or because Grad finds a better tradeoff at improving p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rather than directly minimizing p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, even when λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0, precisely because of the relatively small value of p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT relative to p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In all cases, however, Grad acheives a higher p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and lower p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT than other policies.

We also plot the effect of increasing the ratio between α𝙷/α𝙽𝙷subscript𝛼𝙷subscript𝛼𝙽𝙷\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}/\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Fig. 14. As harmful content becomes more attractive, we see that the gradient collapses into alternating maximization. All policies also degrade in terms of p𝙲𝙻𝙺subscript𝑝𝙲𝙻𝙺p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p𝙷subscript𝑝𝙷p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as harmful content becomes more attractive, as shown in Figs. 15 and 16, respectively.

Increasing the Recommendation Set Size k𝑘kitalic_k. Table 5 gives the parameter values for k𝑘kitalic_k and c𝑐citalic_c for Figures 6, 17, and 18, when either c𝑐citalic_c is fixed, or k/c𝑘𝑐k/citalic_k / italic_c is fixed.
